plants.name: Rhododendron ponticum
plants.description: A large, evergreen shrub producing dense clusters of bell-shaped flowers, often in shades of purple, pink, or white. It thrives in temperate regions and is popular in gardens and parks.
plants.location: Native to southern Europe and southwest Asia; commonly found in the UK and parts of North America.
plants.funFact: Rhododendrons can be toxic to humans and animals due to grayanotoxins present in their nectar and leaves.

plants.name: Acer palmatum
plants.description: While primarily known for their stunning foliage, certain cultivars of Japanese Maple produce small reddish flowers in spring. These blooms are subtle but mark the tree's emerging leaves.
plants.location: Native to Japan, Korea, and China; widely cultivated worldwide.
plants.funFact: Japanese Maples are highly prized for their delicate leaf shapes and brilliant fall color, but their spring flowers are often overlooked.

plants.name: Cornus florida
plants.description: This deciduous tree produces large white or pink bracts surrounding small inconspicuous flowers, creating a showy floral display in spring.
plants.funFact: Flowering Dogwood bracts, often mistaken for petals, serve to attract pollinators to the small central flowers.

plants.name: Erythronium americanum
plants.description: A spring ephemeral wildflower with striking yellow, nodding flowers and mottled leaves resembling trout patterns. It grows in deciduous forests.
plants.funFact: Yellow Trout Lilies spread primarily through underground rhizomes, forming large clonal colonies in woodland floors.
